She would like to apply for a new 20,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Rebecca dreams that her business will grow more and more successful and hopes to live a happy life with her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecila is 49 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She owns and operates a motorcycle transport business in the local community to earn a living. She has been with her business for over 5 years and earns about 8,000 PHP every month. She joined GDMPC in the year 2008, and now she has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase spare parts and new tires. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and new tires.

loans.name: Experito

texts.en:
A married father of 12 children, 2 of whom are currently in school, 50-year-old Experito lives in the town of Matugga in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past two years he has been working hard to manage his restaurant, which sells local food.

To help expand his business, Experito has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to obtain a deep freezer; this will help him to generate greater profits and improve his family's living standards. Experito hopes that in the future he will be able to start a small take-away business.

Experito is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like him who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to obtain a deep freezer.

loans.name: Paulinah

texts.en:
Paulinah is 45 years old and a mother of three children. She has a polythene selling business in Tala town. She has been in the business for three years and it is profitable. Besides this business, she also keeps dairy livestock.

This is her first loan term and she plans to use the amount to buy more stock of polythene bags to sell in her business. Most of her customers are traders from the marketplace. She anticipates generating more income which she will use to pay school fees for her children. She also plans to use part of the loan amount to buy feeds for her livestock.

Paulinah hopes to expand her business by supplying polythene bags to other market traders in other areas of Tala town.

loans.use: To buy more stock of polythene bags to sell.

loans.name: Galo

texts.en:
Galo earns a living through his hog-raising business. He lives with his family in Ubay, Bohol and has been in the business for more than one year now. 

Galo is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets to raise as well as pig feeds. With this, he will be able to improve his business and makes it a success. Galo dreams of expanding his hog-raising business in order to augment his income.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets to raise and pig feeds.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en: Mercedes is 59 years old. She operates a hog-fattening business as a source of income. After four or five months, she sells her hogs at a profitable price. She is applying for a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs. This will make her hogs healthier and will enable her to earn a higher income.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.en:
Anastasia is a 62-year-old widow. She lives in Telavi, East Georgia, with her two daughters, Maia and Tinatin. Anastasia requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan requests were rejected all the time because of her low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of the income for the family is the small monthly salary of Anastasia. She is professional accountant and gets private orders to do accountancy for different companies. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Anastasia requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Anastasia will purchase a sewing machine and materials for sewing bedclothes. She has a basement in her house, which will be used as a workshop, so she will not have to pay money for rent. The bedclothes she makes will be sold locally at the markets and among her villagers. As Anastasia won’t have too many expenses except buying materials, she hopes the business will be profitable. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family, and Anastasia will be able to provide a better life for her daughters.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and materials for sewing bedclothes.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en: Lucena, 48 years old, is married. They were blessed with three children. She's into selling fruits and vegetables in their village; with this business, she's earning a net income of 2,800 PHP (Philippines pesos). She would like to a loan amounting to 7,000 PHP to purchase vegetables and fruits to sell such as eggplant, squash, string beans and bananas. She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that she can be able to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and fruits to sell such as eggplant, squash, string beans and bananas.

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is 54 years old, married, and has three children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. 

She owns farmland, planting and harvesting rice for sale to earn a living. She has been in her business for over eight years and earns 30,000 PHP every month. 

She joined GDMPC in 2008, and now she has requested a loan of 35,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
This is Rosana. She previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts and accessories, and for the maintenance of their jeepney unit. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan for her to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their jeepney. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Rosana dreams of expanding her business and hopes to have a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship** members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers in helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney: open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly the Philippines.

** All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and the maintenance of their jeepney.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa is a 41-year-old married woman and the mother of three children from CPG, Bohol. She is a farmer and has been in the farming business for more than 6 years now. She works hard to support her husband in tilling their farm.

Elisa is asking for a loan to buy additional seedlings, fertilizers and pesticides. With this, they will be able to improve their farming business and harvest.

loans.use: to buy additional seedlings, fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.name: Balakhan

texts.en:
Balakhan is 21 years old and lives with his mother. After his father's death, he is continuing his agriculture activity. 

Balakhan sells milk products and meat, so he is the only breadwinner in the family. He owns land where he raises grass for animals, additionally, in a season, he plants watermelon, melon and cucumber and his mother helps him to sell it. 

He has more than six of years experience in this field, so the expansion of his farm is very important to him.

Balakhan has applied for this loan to purchase field sowing tools and watermelon seeds. This will expand his agriculture activity and will help him to gather more income. This loan is very important for Balakhan to cover his family's basic costs and improve his living conditions. He plans to do renovation work at home and to get married soon.

loans.use: To purchase field sowing tools and watermelon seeds.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a 48-year-old lady from Vihiga County, married to Elly, who is a businessman. They have three children, 23, 19 and 15 years old.

Ruth is a tailor who makes dresses and sells them to her customers. This is a business she’s done for the past 13 years, earning a monthly income of KES 4,000.

This is her second loan from KADET Ltd., which she plans to use to buy more rolls of fabric materials for making dresses in her business. 

The anticipated profits will be used to grow the business and educate her children. Her dream is to become a successful business woman in the region.

loans.use: To purchase rolls of fabric.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is 32 years old and a resident of Namugoona, an outskirt of the city. She is married with 2 children and one of them attends school. Prossy sells shoes. She started the business in 2008 so as improve on her daily income. 

She went to school up to the level of secondary school, but her parents failed to continue with her studies due to the lack of funds to finance her studies. Therefore, she dropped out of school and decided to work as a house helper, from which she saved some small amount of money and decided to start up a small restaurant, which also challenged her, and later she tried selling secondhand shoes. 

Prossy’s customers are mostly ladies, men and children around the area, and also other retailers. Prossy received a loan of 2,500,000 UGX to finish her small house so that she might be able to save the money she was paying for rent. She will use just a small portion to buy more stock of shoes.

Her major challenges are inadequate capital, competitors and rent charges. Prossy is a hardworking woman, and her aim is to have a good and big business that will help her improve her income and have a better life with her family.

loans.use: To buy building materials to finish her incomplete house.

loans.name: Rapik

texts.en:
Rapik, 28 years old, lives with his wife and parents in Dmanisi District. His parents receive a retirement pension. Rapik requested loans from local financial institutions several times to start a new family business, but without success. His requests were consistently rejected due to low income and the family’s poor living conditions.

The only source of income for the family is their agricultural activities. They sell sheep locally and currently have a flock of 35. They also grow potatoes and maize on a plot of land they own, selling them locally at a good price.

Rapik requested a loan from Credo to start a family business that entails purchasing calves to raise and eventually sell. This will improve both the income and living conditions of the family His loan request was approved in the frames of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up loan program envisages provision of business startup and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

loans.use: to purchase calves to raise and sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a 48-year-old married woman and a mother of four children from CPG, Bohol. She has been working in a fishing business for more than 10 years now with her husband. This is the source of their income.

Josephine is asking for a loan to buy a new boat engine and fishing nets. With this, her husband can enhance his catch, thus allowing them to sell more fish in the market.

loans.use: To buy a new boat engine and fishing nets

loans.name: Merla

texts.en: Merla, a 58-year-old widowed mother of three, has been managing a piggery business for almost two years, earning a net income amounting to Php 2,000 per hog sold. Merla would like to avail a loan amounting to Php 25,000 to purchase hog feeds and hogs to raise. She is hoping that her income will grow so that her business will become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase hog feeds and hogs to raise.

loans.name: Myrliza

texts.en:
Myrliza, 36 years old, lives happily with her husband in a rural community. Due to financial hardships, she raises hogs to help her husband in generating income. They aim to earn and save more to improve their house and save for their future.

To this end, Myrliza wants to improve her hog-raising business and so is requesting a loan of PHP 50,000.00 to buy feeds, vitamins, vaccines and additional piglets to raise. Through this financial assistance, she is hoping to expand her enterprise.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamins, vaccines and additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a 61-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She runs a sari-sari or variety store business selling various goods and commodities to the people in her place. Lydia wants to expand her business but lacks the financial resources to do so. She joined CEVI to gain access to the loan services offered by the organization to small entrepreneurs like her. She is asking for a loan to buy additional groceries to sell like canned goods, candies, biscuits, rice, soap, soda, and toiletries. 

In the future, Lydia hopes to sustain her business so that it will continue generating income.

loans.use: to buy additional groceries to sell like canned goods, candies, biscuits, rice, soap, soda, and toiletries

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 43 years old and a mother from Vihiga county in the western part of Kenya. She is married to Ebrahim and  they have been blessed with four children whose ages are 23, 20, 16 and 13 years old, respectively.

Gladys operates a retail shop. She has been doing this business for 11 years and makes a monthly income of 5,800 KES. She is taking her second loan after having completed the previous one in time. She will use this loan to increase the volume of the stock by purchasing sugar, maize flour, cooking fat and cooking oil for sale to the community. She will use the anticipated profits to grow her business.

Gladys has a dream of becoming a successful business lady and educating her children into a higher level of education.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of sugar, maize flour and cooking fat

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans les familles polygames, les six  femmes du groupe Benkadi  ont en moyenne 32 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Togo dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage. Elles font le petit commerce de condiment « Soumbala », de céréales et du bois de chauffe. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 11ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Mariama  (femme debout à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) a une grande renommée  dans la vente du condiment « Soumbala » de qualité dans le village et au marché Médine de Ségou. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 400kg d’amandes de Néré. Elle se ravitaille en noix de Néré avec les forains de Konobougou au grand marché de Ségou. 
Pour préparer le Soumbala, on l’imbibe dans l’eau pendant 2 jours au moins puis on le rince avec de l’eau propre avant de l’étuver. On le broye dans le mortier avant de le laver proprement avec de l’eau simple. Les amandes ainsi broyés seront renfermées dans des sacs plastiques avec un peu de potasse pendant 3 jours au moins pour fermentation. Ce mélange obtenu est le condiment Soumbala très appétissant dans toutes les sauces. 
La revente se fait au comptant  et à crédit à domicile et dans les quartiers de Ségou en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Mariama  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer l’entretien des enfants du foyer.
texts.en:
The six members of the Benkadi group are married women who live for the most part in polygamous families in the village of Togo, region of Segou (4th administrative region of Mali). They average 32 years of age and four children each. They know one another as neighbors and through ties of marriage and kinship. They work in small trade selling Soumbala (a condiment), cereals and firewood. 

To bolster their working capital, the group members joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is their 11th group loan cycle. 

Mrs. Mariama (standing at the far left in the photo) enjoys a great reputation as a seller of high-quality Soumbala in the village and at the market of Médine in Segou. She will use her loan to buy 400 kg of néré nuts. She buys her stock from Konobougou stall-holders at the big market of Ségou.

Soumbala is made by soaking the néré nuts in water for at least two days. The nuts are rinsed with plain water and drained, then ground with a mortar and rinsed again with plain water. The ground nuts are placed in plastic bags with a small amount of potash for at least three days to ferment. The resulting mixture is the condiment Soumbala, a popular addition to all kinds of sauces.

Mrs. Mariama sells her product cash and on credit from her home and door-to-door around the districts of Ségou to a clientèle consisting mainly of women. She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA, which she will use to provide for the children in her household and to invest in her activity.

loans.use: to buy néré nuts.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia, a 35-year-old single mother of two children, both currently in school, lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past six years, Patricia has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells food and soft drinks.

Patricia has requested a loan of 3000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to improve the business and buy more soft drinks to sell. This will help her to generate greater profits, expand the restaurant, and look after her family more effectively. Patricia hopes that in the future she will be able to start another business.

Patricia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Patricia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to improve the business and buy more soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Vivien

texts.en:
Vivien is 39 years old, from Kaimosi and married to Wilson. They have three children ages 17, 12, and 9 years old.

Vivien operates a green grocery business and she has been in this business for the past six years earning a monthly income of 5,000 KES. This is her third loan from KADET LTD, a loan of 20,000 KES, which she intends to buy more stock of vegetables and fruits in bulk from farmers to sell.

The anticipated profit will be used to grow the business and repay the loan. Her dream is to venture into another business and give her children the best education.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 28 years old. He lives in Batumi, West Georgia with his retired father, Guri, who is 75 years old. Several times, David requested a loan from local financial institutions for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time because of low income and his family’s poor living conditions. 

The only sources of income for the family are Guri's monthly pension and a small salary of David's, who is working as an artisan in a private building company. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the 'subsistence poor' category. 

David requested loan from Credo to start-up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as 'high risk borrowers' because of low income. 

With the received loan, David will buy all materials needed to renovate a flat. After the flat is renovated, he plans to rent it out. Because of tourism development in Batumi, David believes that renovating this flat will help him to earn more income. This new business initiative, financed with a start-up loan from Kiva, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family and David will be able to take better care of his aged father.

loans.use: to buy all materials needed to renovate a flat.

loans.name: Maria Mercedes

texts.es:
María Mercedes tiene 47 años de edad es soltera tiene 2 hijos vive con sus padres e hijos.

Es Integrante de la VRC Arrayapamba se encuentra formada por 12 socios que son de la misma comunidad a 25 minutos de la oficina de la cooperativa, la actividad económica es la agricultura, crianza de animales y comercio.

Marìa Mercedes se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, frejol, mora y además se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, pollos y ganado. 

Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas,abonos, insectisida, ranger, polvillo, balanceado, morocho y el arriendo de los pastizales.

Las compras las realiza en la ciudad de Chillanes y sus ventas las hace en la misma ciudad. El sueño es tener recursos para aumentar la producción, comprarse una casa y terreno para vivir mas comodamente. 

Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta son: pocos ingresos económicos, precios bajos en la producción.   
En el tiempo libre le gusta visitar familiares, ver televisión, disfrutar de las festividades de la comunidad y el carnaval.
texts.en:
María Mercedes is 47 years old. She is a single woman. She has two children and lives with her parents and children.

She is a member of the Arrayapamba communal bank. The bank has 12 members who are from the same community which is 25 minutes from the cooperative’s office. The members are involved in business activities like farming, raising animals, and trade.

Marìa Mercedes grows corn, beans and blackberries. In addition, she raises pigs, chickens and livestock. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers, insecticides, balanced animal feed and to lease plots of land.

She makes purchases in the city of Chillanes and she sells products in the same city. Her dream is to have resources to increase production, purchase a house and land in order to live more comfortably. 

The challenges she faces include little income and low production prices. 

In her free time, she likes to visit family, watch television, enjoy the festivities in her community and the carnival.

loans.use: purchase seeds, fertilizers, insecticides, balanced animal feed and lease plots of land.

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Nestor has taken out and repaid a loan for PHP 30,000 that he used to buy more fish to sell. The additional money he earned was a big help in meeting his expenses. He has been in this line of work for 20 years and is requesting a new loan, for PHP 50,000, to buy more fish to sell. He hopes this loan will increase his income even more. His goal for the future is to open a second location where he can sell more fish and provide his family with a good life. He meets with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week and draw strength and inspiration from his religion.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who meet to study religion, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy urea, insecticide, ranger, and animal feed.

loans.name: Luis Martin

texts.es:
Luis Martin tiene 36 años de edad es soltero vive con sus padres en chillanes Provincia de Bolìvar.
Es Integrante de la VRC Arrayapamba se encuentra formada por 12 socios que son de la misma comunidad a 25 minutos de la oficina de la cooperativa, la actividad económica es la agricultura, crianza de animales y comercio.

Luis Martin se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, frejol, mora y además se dedica a la crianza ganado. Solicita el crédito para la compra de abonos, insectisida, ranger, polvillo, balanceado, morocho y el arriendo de los pastizales.

Las compras las realiza en la ciudad de Chillanes y sus productos los ofrece en la misma. Su sueño es mejorar las condiciones de vida, tener una buena producción y tener terreno propio. 

Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta son: baja de producción por mal tiempo, presencia de plagas y enfermedades.
En el tiempo libre le gusta hacer deporte en especial jugar boly, futbol disfrutar de las festividades de la comunidad y también en sus carnavales.
texts.en:
Luis Martin, 36, is single and lives with his parents in Chillanes, Bolívar province. He is a member of the communal bank Arrayapamba, composed of twelve members that live in a community located 25 minutes away from the cooperative’s office. The region’s activities are agriculture, livestock farming and commerce.

Luis Martin works in agriculture. He grows corn, beans, blackberry and he also raises cattle. He is requesting a loan to buy compost, insecticides, ranger [a brand of herbicide], polvillo [an animal feed made from rice], morocho [a kind of dense corn] and pay for the pasture’s rent. Luis Martin will buy these supplies in the city of Chillanes, where he sells his produce.

Luis Martin’s dreams are to improve his quality of life, offer good-quality products and to have his own land. The most significant challenge for him is decreased production due to bad weather conditions, plagues and diseases.

During his free time, he likes to play sports, especially volleyball and football. He also likes to take part in local celebrations and carnivals.

loans.use: to buy compost, insecticide, herbicide and feed, and to pay for the pasture's rent.

loans.name: Cirilo

texts.es: El Sr. Cirilo tiene 30 años y 1 bebe de 10 meses, el se dedica a la Agricultura sembrando variedad de vegetales como también papa y yuca y maíz en su parcela que se encuentra en la comunidad de Lagunilla,  este préstamo es el su primera secuencia dentro de la institución,  El Sr. Cirilo va a utilizar  este préstamo para la siembra de papa  y lo que implica el preparado de la tierra, su razón para solicitar este préstamo es para obtener recursos  para la siembra y poder subsistir, El Sr. Cirilo enfrenta retos en su negocio que son las inclemencias del clima que en muchas ocasiones arruinan los sembradíos,  y utilizara los beneficios Para mejorara la calidad de vida del cliente y de su familia ya que el corre con todos los gastos del hogar, es una persona  responsable y trabajador se siente agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Cirilo is 30 and has a 10-month-old baby. He grows a variety of vegetables like potatoes, yuca, and corn on his land in Lagunilla. This is his first loan cycle with the institution. Cirilo will use the loan to prepare his land to plant potatoes. He needs the loan to have resources to plant and be able to substitute. 

Bad weather, which often can ruin crops, is one of the challenges Cirilo faces. He will use the income from his business to improve his family's living conditions, as he pays all the household expenses. He is responsible and hardworking. He thanks the institution for its support.

loans.use: to plant potatoes.

loans.name: Alicia Fernanda

texts.es:
Alicia Fernanda tiene 28 años de edad es soltera vive con sus padres en Chillanes Provincia de Bolivar.

Es Integrante de la VRC Arrayapamba se encuentra formada por 12 socios que son de la misma comunidad a 25 minutos de la oficina de la cooperativa, la actividad económica es la agricultura, crianza de animales y comercio.

Alicia Fernanda se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, frejol, mora y además se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, pollos y ganado. Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas,abonos, insectisida, ranger, polvillo, balanceado, morocho y el arriendo de los pastizales.

Las compras las realiza en la ciudad de Chillanes y sus ventas las hace en la misma ciudad. El sueño es tener casa y terreno propio. 

Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta son: las plagas en los cultivos dañan la producción. En el tiempo libre le gusta visitar familiares, salir a pasear, disfrutar de las festividades de la comunidad, y en carnaval.
texts.en:
Alicia Fernanda, 28, is single and lives with her parents in Chillanes Province in Bolivar. She belongs to the communal bank Arrayapamba, which comprises 12 members from the same community about 25 minutes from the cooperative's office. The members farm and raise livestock and are merchants.

Alicia Fernanda grows corn, beans, and mulberries and raises pigs, chickens, and cattle. She is applying for a loan to buy seed, fertilizer, insecticide, ranger, and animal feed and to lease pastureland. She buys and sells in Chillanes.

She dreams of having her own house and land. Pests that harm the crops are one of her challenges. In her free time, she likes to visit relatives, go for a walk, and enjoy the local festivals and carnival.

loans.use: to buy seed, fertilizer, insecticide, ranger, and animal feed and to lease pastureland.

loans.name: Luis Patricio

texts.es:
Luis Patricio tiene 24 años de edad es soltero vive con los padres en Chillanes Provincia de Bolìvar.

Es Integrante de la VRC Arrayapamba se encuentra formada por 12 socios que son de la misma comunidad a 25 minutos de la oficina de la cooperativa, la actividad económica es la agricultura, crianza de animales y comercio.

Luis Patricio se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, frejol, mora y además se dedica a la crianza de cerdos. Solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas,abonos, insectisida, ranger, polvillo, balanceado.

Las compras las realiza en la ciudad de Chillanes y sus ventas las hace en la misma. Su sueño es comprar terreno. 

Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es la falta de capital para trabajar.

En el tiempo libre le gusta hacer deporte en especial jugar boly, futbol disfrutar de las festividades de la comunidad y también en sus carnavales.
texts.en:
Luis Patricio, 24, is single and lives with his parents in Chillanes Province in Bolìvar. He belongs to the communal bank Arrayapamba, which comprises 12 members from the same community about 25 minutes from the cooperative's office. The members farm and raise livestock and are merchants.

Luis Patricio grows corn, beans, and mulberries and raises pigs. He is applying for a loan to buy seed, fertilizer, insecticide, ranger, and animal feed. He buys and sells in Chillanes. He dreams of buying land. His challenge is lack of capital. In his free time, he likes to play soccer and enjoy the local festivals and carnivals.

loans.use: to buy seed, fertilizer, insecticide, ranger, and animal feed.

loans.name: Latifa

texts.en: Latifa is a 30-year-old Lebanese woman who is married and the mother of two children. She is trying hard to supplement her husband's income, which he earns by working in a local fuel station. To earn money, she opened a flower shop in 2007. She sells a wide variety of items, but is applying for this youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to buy more flowers and other items for her shop. This will increase the number of customers asking for her services. Her goal for the future is to enlarge her shop by adding a wider selection of flowers.

loans.use: to buy flowers and other items for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more cement, hoes and pangas to sell

loans.name: Maria Cecelia

texts.en: Maria Cecelia runs a sari-sari or variety store business for a living. She sells various goods and items to the people in her community. Maria Cecelia is asking for a loan to buy additional stocks to sell like canned goods, chips and biscuits, sopa and toiletries, cooking ingredients and seasonings. Through this, she will be able to improve her store and augment her sales and income.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks to sell like canned goods, chips and biscuits, sopa and toiletries, cooking ingredients and seasonings

loans.name: Ma. Beverly

texts.en: Ma. Beverly is a 40-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She has three children who range in age from 12 to 18 years old. She earns a living by farming. Ma. Beverly has been in this business for five years and currently grows rice. Her husband is also a farmer. She is requesting a loan buy fertilizer and seedlings. This will make her crops grow faster and allow her to earn more income. Her goal for the future is to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
This is Yolanda. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more fruits and vegetables needed in her business. Her business has been running for three years now and it keeps on growing. She sells carrots, bananas, squash, eggplant, potatoes, cabbage, papayas, mangoes and more. Customers are attracted to buy because of her wide range of choices. She and her husband, who is working in a hotel, work hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to purchase more fruits and vegetables needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and meet the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Yolanda hopes to have another stall and dreams that her children will finish their studies. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from her studies of the Word of God. 


* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. Fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more fruit and vegetables needed in her business.

loans.name: Loida

texts.en: Loida is 57 years old and blessed with five adult-age children. To generate income, she is engaged in a hog-raising business while her husband cultivates their farmland. She aimed to improve the business and increase her income in order to satisfy their necessities and support the education of her grandchild. She planned to raise more pigs to sell but she has inadequate capital. In this regard, she is asking for an additional PHP 30,000.00 loan to buy the needed feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise. She is hoping that someday, she will improve the business and make it more profitable.

loans.use: to buy the needed feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin is 51 years old, married and the mother of five children. She lives with her family in a village in Kompong Speu province, where she owns and operates a farm. Her husband works in a metal shop where he makes doors, windows and fences, and her goal is to supplement his income. She is requesting a loan from HKL to invest in a new business so that she can earn additional income for her household. She is seeking a loan for $1,500 to buy a set of speakers which can be rented out to neighbors on special occasions such as parties. She hopes that this new business will allow her to improve her living conditions. In coming years, she wants to provide more services to people in her community.

loans.use: to buy speakers which she can rent out to neighbors for special occasions.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 49-year-old mother from Vihiga county, in the western part of Kenya. She is a widow and a mother of four children, the first-born being twins who are now 29 years old. The other two children are 23 and 17 years old.

Beatrice was introduced to the Kenya Agency for Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) by the group members. Since then, she has been a cooperative member of the group. 

Beatrice has a cereals stall in Vihiga town. She has been selling cereals for the last 13 years and makes a monthly income of KES 5,000. 

Beatrice has applied for a second loan with KADET, which she will use to increase her stock by purchasing maize, millet, and beans to sell. She will use the anticipated profit to expand her business. She has a dream of educating her children and increasing the strength of her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize, millet, and beans to sell in her cereals stall.

loans.name: Kankelen Group

texts.fr:
Mariées toutes dans les familles polygames, les quatre femmes du groupe Kankelen ont en moyenne 43 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Togo dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage. Elles font le petit commerce de céréales, calebasses, bois de chauffe, mortiers et pilons gravés. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 7ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Mamou (femme debout à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) est une grande artiste dans la gravure des calebasses, pilons et mortiers dans le village et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 25 mortiers et 30 pilons. Ils sont ensuite gravés de beaux dessins et slogan à l’aide d’une pince que l’on rougit avec le feu selon le goût de la clientèle. La revente se fait au comptant  et à crédit à domicile et dans les quartiers de Ségou en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Mamou espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer les soins de santé des enfants du foyer.
texts.en:
The four members of the Kankelen group are married and living in polygamous families. The average 43 years of age, with three children. They all live in the Togo village in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali) and know each other as neighbors and relatives by blood or marriage. They retail cereals,  gourds, firewood,  mortars and pestles. 

In order to expand their working capital, the group members have decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are no on their 7th solidarity loan. Mrs. Mamou (the one standing on the far left in the photo) is a real artist known in her village and the nearby region for engraving gourds, mortars and pestles. She plans to use her loan to buy 30 mortars and 30 pestles. She will then engrave them with beautiful designs and slogans, as per her clients' wishes, using a cutting tool heated on the fire. She sells for cash and on credit, out of her home and in various areas of Segou, as a street vendor, to a customer base consisting mainly of women. Thanks to this loan, Mrs. Mamou hopes to earn an average monthly revenue of 35,000 West African francs, which will be used to reinvest in her business and provide for her children’s healthcare expenses.

loans.use: to buy mortars and pestles.

loans.name: Humberto Washington

texts.es:
Humberto Washington tiene 40 años de edad es soltero y tiene un hijo de 10 años vive con sus padres en Chillanes Provincia de Bolìvar.

Es Integrante de la VRC Arrayapamba se encuentra formada por 12 socios que son de la misma comunidad a 25 minutos de la oficina de la cooperativa, la actividad económica es la agricultura, crianza de animales y comercio.

Humberto Washington se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, frejol, mora y además se dedica a la crianza de ganado. Solicita el crédito para la compra de urea, insectisida, ranger, polvillo, balanceado.
Las compras las realiza en la ciudad de Chillanes y sus ventas las hace en la misma. Su suño es tener terreno propio y pastizales para el ganado y que mejore el precio de los productos. 

Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta son: la baja de precio en los productos y el mal tiempo daña la producción.
En el tiempo libre le gusta salir a pasear, hacer deporte, disfrutar de las fiestas de la comunidad y sus carnavales.
texts.en:
Humberto Washington is forty years old.  He is single and has one son, who is ten years old.  He lives with his parents in Chillanes, in the province of Bolivar.  

He is a member of the Arrayapamba Communal Bank, which is made up of twelve members who are all from the same community.  It takes twenty-five minutes to get from their community to the office.  The members make a living in agriculture, raising animals, and in trade.  

Humberto Washington makes a living in agriculture, specifically in growing corn, beans, and blackberries, and in raising livestock.  He is requesting a loan in order to buy urea, insecticide, herbicide, rice-based animal feed, and corn-based animal feed.  He buys these items in the city of Chillanes and he also sells his products in this same location.  

His dream is to have his own land and pastures for the livestock, and to improve the price of his products.  

The challenges he faces are: the decrease in price of his products and bad weather, which hurts production.

In his free time he likes to go out for walks, play sports, and enjoy the parties and festivals of the community.

loans.use: to buy urea, insecticide, herbicide, rice-based animal feed, and corn-based animal feed.

loans.name: Lazar

texts.en: Lazar is 26 years old, single and lives with his family in the southern part of Kosovo. He is very hardworking and does many things to earn his income.  Currently he is working as a taxi driver and this is his family's main source of income. Lazar is requesting a loan for 1,300 euros to improve his family's life by renovating their house. This loan will also help him save money on utility bills. His goal is to save money for the future, and he wishes to thank all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: to renovate his house.

loans.name: Flor Semira

texts.es:
Flor Semira tiene 53 años de edad es casada vive con sus hijos y el esposo en Chillanes Provincia de Bolìvar.

Es Integrante de la VRC Arrayapamba se encuentra formada por 12 socios que son de la misma comunidad a 25 minutos de la oficina de la cooperativa, la actividad económica es la agricultura, crianza de animales y comercio.

Flor Semira se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, frejol, mora y además se dedica a la crianza de cerdos y pollos. Solicita el crédito para la compra de urea, insectisida, ranger, polvillo, morocho, balanceado y comprar 2 pollos.

Las compras las realiza en Chillanes y las vende en Montalvo. El sueño es mejorar las condiciones y tener una casita propia. 

Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es la baja producción y precios bajos de los productos.

En el tiempo libre le gusta visitar familiares, ver televisión, disfrutar de las festividades de la comunida y en carnaval.
texts.en:
Flor Semira is fifty-three years old and is married.  She lives with her children and husband in Chillanes, in the province of Bolivar.  

She is a member of Arrayapamba Communal Bank, which is made up of twelve members who are all from the same community.  It takes twenty-five minutes to get to the office from their community.  The members make a living in agriculture, raising animals, and in trade.  

Flor Semira makes a living in agriculture, in growing corn, beans, and blackberries, and also in raising pigs and chickens.  She is requesting the loan in order to buy urea, insecticide, herbicide, rice-based animal feed, dense corn, corn-based animal feed, and two chickens.

She buys all her items in Chillanes, and she sells her products in Montalvo.  Her dream is to improve her conditions and to have her own small house. 

The challenges she faces are: low production and low prices for her products.  

In her free time, she likes to visit relatives, watch television, and enjoy the community and Carnaval festivals.

loans.use: to buy urea, insecticide, herbicide, rice-based animal feed, dense corn, corn-based animal feed, and two chickens.

loans.name: Hector Alexis

texts.es:
Hector tiene 38 años de edad, es casado, tiene 2 hijos, vive en una aldea de Taulabe, Comayagua.
Hector se dedica desde muy joven a la agricultura, el posee una manzana de tierra cultivada con café, el cual comercializa en distinta variedad pergamino húmedo  café uva y oro. Al realizar las ventas el obtiene buenas ganancias ya que el café es de buena calidad, el lugar donde vive es apto para este tipo de cultivo.
Actualmente ha solicitado el préstamo numero 12 por lqa cantidad de 25000 lempira para comprar de fertilizante,  siembra de ½ manzana de café, limpieza y mantenimiento de la finca.
Su planes es  seguir dando mantenimiento a los cultivos y que sean tolerables a las enfermedades, como la rolla. También piensa aumentar sus ingresos para culminar la educación de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Hector, 38, is married and has two children; he lives in a village in Taulabe, Comayagua.  He’s worked in agriculture since he was very young.  He has a manzana [Central American unit of land measurement] planted with coffee that he sells in various varieties like damp parchment, grape coffee and gold.  He earns good profits from his sales because his coffee is good quality.  The place where he lives is apt for this type of crop.  

He’s currently asking for his 12th loan for 25,000 Lempiras to buy fertilizer to plant one-half manzana of coffee, to clear the fields and to provide crop maintenance.  His plan is to continue caring for his crops so they can resist illnesses like ‘roya’ [coffee blight].  He also plans to increase his income in order to complete his children’s education.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a 29-year-old lady from Vihiga County. She is a single mother with one child who is five years old.

Pauline is a hairdresser, a business she has done for the past three years, earning a monthly income of KES 4,500. This is her second loan with KADET LTD, which she intends to use to purchase a hair dryer for the business 

The anticipated profits will be used to open another business of selling new clothes and also pay fees for her daughter's education. Her dream is to give her daughter the best education and also succeed in the business sector.

loans.use: to purchase a hair dryer

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa, de 48 años, es una mujer alegre y muy trabajadora, esta casada con José, con quien tiene 04 hijos de 26, 21, 18  y 10 años, tiene una casa propia en donde vive a lado de su pareja y sus hijos.El trabajo de Rosa  consiste en la venta de bebidas gasificadas ,actividad que realiza desde su hogar , actualmente no cuenta con una refrigeradora es por eso que compra a diario barras de hielo y en una bandeja de plástico refrigera su bebidas gasificadas, además tiene algunas cosas mas en venta, entre ellas panecillos y kekes caseros con los que sus clientes acompañan sus bebidas, lleva ya 03 años en este trabajo y lo hace sola ya que su pareja se dedica a otras actividades.
Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que tiene tiempo para poder hacer las actividades en su hogar, tiene buenos clientes.Por tanto éste será el préstamo numero 01 con Kiva y esta muy agradecida por la oportunidad de aumentar su capital y tener mejores ingresos.Con el monto solicitado de S/.1000 soles, comprará mas bebidas, entre ellas gaseosas en envase de vidrio y en envases descartables, con esto tendrá una buena cantidad de productos y más bebidas para sus clientes.
texts.en:
Rosa is 48 years old. She is a very hardworking, happy woman. She is married to Jose with whom she has 4 children ages 26, 21, 18 and 10. She owns her own home where she lives with her husband and children. Rosa works from home and sells soft drinks for a living. She has to buy blocks of ice and keep her beverages cold in a cooler because she doesn't have a refrigerator. She also sells homemade baked goods for her customers to eat with their beverages. She has been doing this on her own for 3 years since her husband has his own jobs.

What she likes about her job is that she also has time to take care of household responsibilities and that she has good customers. This will be her first loan through Kiva and she is very grateful for the opportunity to increase her capital and her income. With the S/.1000 soles requested she will buy more beverages in glass and disposable containers so she can stock a larger quantity of products and offer her customers more beverages.

loans.use: purchase soft drinks.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
This is Erlinda. She previously accessed a PHP 16,000 loan that she utilized to buy gardening materials and supplies needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another loan, this time in the amount of PHP 18,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy gardening materials, like wire and baskets and supplies, such as seed and fertilizer needed in her business. Her profits from this business will definitely help her sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Erlinda hopes for continuous growth in her business and dreams to have a good life. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for gardening materials and supplies for her business.

loans.name: Matea

texts.en:
This is Matea. She previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to buy gardening materials and supplies needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another loan, this time for 40,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy gardening materials like wire and baskets, and supplies such as seed and fertilizer needed in her business. Her profits from his business will definitely help her sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Matea hopes for the continuous success of her business and dreams of having a peaceful life. She meets up every week with her *co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business. She also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizer and garden inputs for her business.

loans.name: Alex

texts.es: El Sr. Alex, tiene 28 años, es casado tiene dos hijos de las edades de 5 y 8 años, el se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pan, su panadería  se encuentra ubicado  en la localidad de el Torno,   este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, el Sr. Alex va a usar este préstamo para la compra de  harina, manteca y levadura por mayor ya quiere incrementar su producción y así satisfacer la demandada de sus clientes, el Sr. Alex enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia ya que existen varias panaderías en la localidad, con este crédito mejorara sus ganancias, el Sr. Alex es una persona joven  con ganas de superación se siente feliz y agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Alex, 28, is married and has two children aged 5 and 8.  He works baking and selling bread.  His bakery is located in El Torno.  This loan is his first with the institution and Alex will use it to buy flour, shortening and yeast at wholesale because he wants to increase production to meet customer demand.

The business challenge Alex faces is competition because there are several bakeries locally.  His profits will improve with this loan.  Alex is a young man who very much wants to improve and feels happy and grateful to the institution for the support provided.

loans.use: to buy flour and shortening at wholesale.

loans.name: Nadia

texts.es: Nadia de  29 años de edad vive con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 9 años y 3 meses al sur occidente de la ciudad donde ofrece los servicios de internet  y transcripciones en su pequeño negocio ubicado en su domicilio. Hace 5 años la necesidad de los habitantes de su barrio y la de apoyar el progreso de su hogar, fueron elementos claves para emprende la oferta de sus servicios, los cuales ha sostenido durante todo este tiempo. Las consultas documentales de los estudiantes en los colegios es su más fuerte línea de trabajo, que efectúa durante 12 horas diarias todos los días de la semana. Previamente recibió un financiamiento de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual compró materiales y construir su local porque necesita tener una imagen superior que venda a otros sectores y aumente cada vez más su clientela. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, segundo financiamiento que hace a esta organización, mediante el cual comprará una fotocopiadora y papelería para agregar un servicio más a su oferta y desarrollar su muchas más posibilidades de crecer con la modernización y actualización permanente de sus equipos.
texts.en:
Nadia, 29, lives with her spouse and two children whose ages are nine years and three months in the southwest part of the city where she offers Internet access and transcription services in her small, home-based business.  Needs of her neighbors and the desire to help support her home’s progress were key elements that led her to start her business five years ago and she’s been offering these services ever since.  Her main customers are students from local schools needing to do research.  She’s open 12 hours daily, every day of the week.

She got a previous Fundación Mario Santo Domingo loan that she used to buy supplies and to build her site because she needed to improve its appearance so she could sell to other sectors and increase clientele more each time.  She’s currently applying for a Kiva loan, her second financing from this organization that she’ll use to buy a photocopier and paper supplies to add another service and develop many more growth possibilities with the modernization and permanent upgrading of her equipment.

loans.use: to buy a photocopier and paper supplies.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame   Mariam  est âgée de 26 ans,  mariée  et mère de 2 enfants, elle vit chez son père  au quartier Pelengana  de Ségou  (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Mariam a laissé  l’école en classe de 8ème année fondamentale (Système Éducatif  Malien) pour mener les activités d’achat et vente  de condiments, apprise auprès de sa mère qui vendait du poisson séché et des condiments au marché Château. Mariam a 8 ans d’expérience  et  jouit d’une grande réputation et clientèle. Elle reçoit fréquemment des commandes venant de  Bamako.
Pour augmenter son fonds dans le souci de faire face à la demande clientèle et de renforcer son commerce,  elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elle est en relation depuis 48 mois. Après 4 prêts  individuels correctement bien remboursés, Mariam est à son 5ème prêt individuel qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 sacs de l’ail et 15 sacs de poivre, elle s’approvisionne à Siribala et Niono.
Madame    Mariam  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de femmes   majoritairement.  Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000FCFA, ce dernier lui servira de prendre en charge certaines dépenses familiales. Son ambition est d’avoir une maison.
texts.en:
Madam Mariam is 26 years old, married and mother to 2 children. She lives at her father's in the Pelengana neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the republic of Mali).

Mariam left school at the 8th fundamental year (Malien educational system) to manage business buying and selling condiments, learned from her mother who sold dried fish and condiments at the Château market. Mariam has 8 years experience and enjoys a great reputation and clientele. She often gets orders from Bamako.

To increase her funds due to the concern of meeting her clientele's demands and to strengthen her business, she resorted to Soro Yiriwaso with which she has been in a relationship for 48 months. After 4 individual loans which were correctly and well repaid, Mariam is on her 5th individual loan which will be used to buy 20 bags of garlic and 15 bags of pepper. She gets her supplies in Siribala and Niono.

Madam Mariam sells for cash and credit to a clientele consisting primarily of women. With this loan she plans to make a monthly profit of 70,000 FCFA. This will serve to take care of certain family expenses. Her ambition is to have a house.

loans.use: to buy condiments.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is a 40-year-old lady from Vihiga County, which is located in the western region of Kenya. She is married to Kennedy, who is 45 years old. They are blessed with three children whose ages are 16, 12, and 8 years old respectively.

Tabitha sells cereals in Vihiga town. She has been doing this business for the last two years and makes a monthly income of KES 5,000. She is taking her second loan from KADET LTD, which she will use to purchase more stock of cereals like maize, groundnuts and millet for sale. She will use the anticipated profit to expand her business.

Her hopes and dreams are to be able to run a successful business and be in a position to provide for her family in a stable way.

loans.use: to buy maize, groundnuts and millet.

loans.name: Luis Alfredo

texts.es:
LUIS ALFREDO tiene 26 años de edad es casado tiene una hija, vive con la esposa y con la hija en la ciudad de Chimbo Provincia de Bolívar.

 LUIS ALFREDO se dedica al comercio de ganado vacuno y porcino. Solicita el crédito para comprar un televisor. 

Con la ayuda del crédito podrá comprar lo que le hace falta para el hogar y estar informado de lo que pase en el mundo entero. Las compras las realizará en la ciudad de Chimbo. El sueño es mejorar el nivel de vida de la hija.

Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es seguir trabajando para cumplir con todo en el hogar. En el timepo libre le gusta salir con la familia a ver los animales.
texts.en: Luis Alfredo, 26, is married and has a daughter; he lives with his wife and daughter in the city of Chimbo, Bolívar Province.  He’s a cattle and pig merchant.  He’s requesting the loan to buy a television set.  With support from the loan he will be able to buy what he needs at home and to be aware of what’s going on in the world.  He will make his purchase in the city of Chimbo.  His dream is to improve his daughter’s standard of living. The challenge he faces is to continue working to meet all his home’s needs. In his free time he enjoys going out with his family to check on the animals.

loans.use: to buy a television set.

loans.name: Zivorad

texts.en:
Zivorad, 53 years old, lives in a minority community in Kosovo. He is married and has one daughter. He works as a construction worker, and his wife is a housewife. Zivorad is the main source of income for his family. 

Zivorad’s house is very old and needs a facade and renovations in order to improve their living conditions. Years ago, he hoped to renovate the house, but there was not enough money.

Now Zivorad requests a loan in order to do renovation. The loan will help him to improve the family’s conditions. He hopes to offer better life conditions to his family. 

Zivorad is very happy for this support and appreciates all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: to renovate his house.

loans.name: Mayram

texts.ru: Майрам замужняя женщина с тремя детьми. Ей 55 лет. Она проживает в районе Дж.Руми. У Майрам имеется дехканское хозяйство, где работают ее двое сыновей. Сама Майрам интересуется животноводством. Она хочет начать бизнес в этой сфере и заняться купле-продажей мелко-рогатого скота. С этой целью Майрам обратилась в организацию за кредитом. Она берет кредит для закупа овец с дальнейшим их откормом и продажей. За счет прибыли с новой деятельности он планирует женить сына.
texts.en: Mayram is  married  and the mother of three. She is 55 years old. She lives in the J. Rumy district. She has a small farm where her two sons work. Mayram is interested in raising livestock. She would like to launch this business and start buying and reselling sheep and goats. With this goal, she has turned to our organization for a loan. She is taking out a loan to buy sheep for fattening and resale. [She] plans to pay for her son’s wedding using her revenues from this new business.

loans.use: to buy sheep for later fattening and resale.

loans.name: Runda Group

texts.en:
Simon’s group has 15 farmers and is located in Chwele District. Simon is pictured on the right of Runda Group with his hand raised. He is pictured amongst the 4 men and 11 women of his group. He will receive input loans capable of planting ½ acre with sorghum, millet, and maize. 

Simon joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. He joined One Acre Fund so that he could access the best input prices and grow enough food for the family.

Simon described his harvest as excellent last year as a One Acre Fund farmer, and hopes for another good year in the 2013 Long Rains season. He plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and buy a cow and land. 

During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Simon’s group will receive 7 ½ acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan, age 78, has been growing cacao nearby his San Jose home for 30 years. Having raised seven daughters who are now all out of the house, Juan and his wife Sabina take care of the household and the farm together, hiring outside help when necessary. 

Juan first got into cacao via a community cacao-farming project. A group of San Jose villagers mobilized into a community to request a land concession from the government on the condition of cultivating cacao in an agroforestry system. Agroforestry refers to a system of land use that involves a combination of agriculture and natural forestry, whereby cash crops like cacao are grown alongside timber trees, conserving the environment and providing a source of income for farmers.  

Cacao has been instrumental for the family to be able to meet their needs. For many Mayan villagers, it is the sole source of income, bringing liquidity to communities that traditionally barter for the goods and services they need. According to Juan, the best thing about cacao is that as long as you are able to work it, it brings in money. Cacao is a tree that once productive continues to yield pods for decades, on the average some 50 years. The most challenging part of growing cacao for Juan is harvesting, because it takes up a lot of time and effort, and is a very messy process.  Cacao pods house about 35 seeds surrounded by a sweet pulp. Harvesting cacao means cracking the pods open to scoop out the seeds, which can then be processed or sold fresh. 

The family is requesting this loan to hire help in the community to clean the cacao fields and for harvesting. Cleaning means clearing the underbrush to make trees accessible for harvest and pruning. Juan says he’s gradually retiring from the farm and is getting ready to hand it over to his older daughter. In the meanwhile, he is happy to hire help to keep his cacao farm healthy and productive.

loans.use: Hire help to clean and harvest cacao.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz de 29 años de edad vive en el municipio de soledad con su cónyuge y sus 3 hijos en las edades de 1 a 8 años. Allí se dedica a dos actividades generadoras de ingresos, por un lado vende mercancía variada como ropa, calzado, y por otro lado vende gallina criolla. Ella desde hace 9 años inició vendiendo mercancía, con la cual atendía las necesidades que presentaba su clientela ubicada en su propio barrio. Gradualmente fue abordando los alrededores de este y muy pronto se hizo conocida en los alrededores de él. Sus productos los propone a crédito y a domicilio,con una frecuencia de dos veces por semana, para recuperar su inversión en periodos semanales, quincenales o mensuales, de acuerdo a lo que pacte con uno a uno de sus clientes. Sus ventas las realiza de contado, atendiendo a su recuperación de su cartera y las hace en la ciudad de Barranquilla, a 20 minutos del municipio donde habita. Su meta mas adelante es adquirir su propia vivienda, pero su mayor desafío es tener la disponibilidad de conseguir los recursos suficientes para atender su mercado, crecer empresarialmente y poder cumplir con su sueño. Luz ya ha recibido créditos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  y está muy satisfecha porque invirtió en un mayor volumen de gallinas criollas que vendió rápidamente. Así mismo le sirvió para comprar mercancía variada con la que respondió a su clientela y ganó un poco mas de dinero, aprovechando cada temporada comercial que pasó. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, con el cual comprará camisas, pantalones, bermudas, calzado y gallinas para que sus dos negocios sigan creciendo simultáneamente y tener la forma de respaldar e invertir sus utilidades. Ella está muy agradecida y pide  lo siguiente  “que sigan apoyando a pequeños empresarios que en un futuro no muy lejano, seremos los grandes empresarios. “su satisfacción es plena porque su rentabilidad ha aumentado en un 35% su clientela es más fuerte y su bienestar  y el de su familias incrementan cada vez mas.
texts.en: Luz is 29 years old and lives in the town of Soledad with her husband and 3 children, ages 1 through 8. She has two income generating jobs, one selling a variety of merchandise such as clothing and shoes and the other selling Creole chicken. She has been selling merchandise for 3 years to fulfill the needs of her customers that live in her own neighborhood. She has been gradually tackling the surrounding area and has become known very quickly in these areas. She sells her products door to door and on credit two times a week to recoup her investment weekly, bimonthly and monthly depending on the agreement she makes with each individual customer. She sells her merchandise on a cash basis in the city of Barranquilla which is 20 minutes away in order to keep a cash flow. Her future goal is to purchase her own home, but her immediate need is to be able to obtain enough resources to tend to and grow her business and eventually fulfill her dream. This is not her first loan through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she is very pleased because she purchased more chickens that she sold quickly. This helped her to purchase a variety of merchandise to meet her customer’s demands and earn a bit more money so she could take advantage of each commercial season. She is currently applying for a Kiva loan to buy shirts, pants, shorts, shoes and chickens so that both of her businesses can continue to grow together and to be able to save and invest her profits. She is very grateful and asks “that lenders continue to support small businesses that, in the not so distant future, will grow into big businesses.”  She is very happy because her profits have grown 35%, her customer base is much stronger and her well being and that of her family has increased more each time.

loans.use: purchase creole chickens, shirts, pants, shorts and shoes.

loans.name: Ponciano

texts.en:
Ponciano, age 60, lives with his wife Escolastica in the village of San Jose, Toledo’s cacao village extraordinaire. The couple has raised three children, two of who currently live in and are attending high school. The family has prioritized their children’s education. “We put them in high school because the times have changed, before we all had to farm,” Ponciano told Maya Mountain Cacao. 

Ponciano started growing cacao at the time of new markets opening up for Belize-grown cacao some 25 years ago. The family manages two acres of cacao farm, with around 900 productive trees. For Ponciano, harvesting is the most rewarding part of cacao farming, as it means instant reimbursement for his work. The most challenging part of cacao farming, however, is cleaning and protecting the trees from animals. Cacao trees are especially vulnerable when they are young, at a time when enthusiastic rodents can overpower the tree by chewing on its soft roots. 

Besides cacao, the family grows the traditional package of corn and beans. Juan also works as a butcher, and sells meat in the market in Toledo district’s capital Punta Gorda. He is interested in expanding his cacao farm to focus more on cacao production, but is currently constrained for land. 

The family is requesting this loan to pay for 15 days of cleaning the fields and to hire three men to help with each harvest. During peak season, farmers harvest cacao at least two times a month. Cacao production this season is reaching its peak in the months of April and May and will gradually start slowing down starting June.

loans.use: To hire hands for cleaning and harvesting cacao.

loans.name: Benito

texts.en:
Benito, 36, and his wife Sarita are raising two children in the village of San Jose in Belize’s southernmost Toledo district. A son of a cacao farmer, Benito got inspired to start his own cacao farm and started by planting 500 trees six years ago.  

Having been exposed to cacao farming from an early age, Benito has taken a liking to it and says that he enjoys everything that goes into cultivating this crop. Cacao is a permanent crop, so once planted and productive, cacao trees continue producing an average of 80 pods a year for decades onward. Maintaining the trees healthy requires cleaning the underbrush about three times a year, and pruning annually to keep production levels high. The hardest part of cacao farming for Benito is fighting monilia – an infectious fungal disease that makes the pods turn black and spreads through their pores. To prevent infection, farmers harvest the infected pods and stow them away from the trees. 

Besides cacao, the family grows rice, corn, beans and plantain for home use, and sells some of it locally. Benito is requesting this loan to do routinely cleaning of his farm and to bag 1,000 seeds for an expansion. Cacao is planted by first raising the seed in a bag filled with topsoil and then transplanting it into the ground. Cacao seedlings are ready for transplantation when they have four leaves, about six months after they are bagged. In the future, Benito hopes his kids can help him out in the growing farm.

loans.use: Hire help to clean cacao field, bag seeds for expansion.

loans.name: Anaweza Group

texts.en:
Benedeta is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Anaweza Group members. The six of them, all women, are farmers in Chwele District. Farming inputs, consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum, will be delivered to Benedeta on credit.

Benedeta first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to receive farm inputs on time and grow enough food for the family.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Benedeta was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize per acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 25 bags per acre! She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to buy clothes and for poultry farming. 

Benedeta’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 3 acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad is 58 years old, married and has four children. 

Trinidad is in the agricultural business, farming bananas in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers for her banana farm.

Trinidad has been farming bananas for six years now, and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Trinidad would like to save enough money to buy more farmland.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her banana farm.

loans.name: Yolanda De Jesús

texts.es: Doña Yolanda de 64 años de edad, es una mujer emprendedora. Reside desde hace más de 30 años en el municipio de Itagüí, Colombia. Y se ha dedicado a  la fabricación y comercialización de arepas. Actividad que se ha constituido en su fuente de ingresos. Diariamente se levanta muy temprano e inicia su faena, elaborando en promedio 80 paquetes de arepas diarios, las cuales distribuye en su barrio. Debido al cansancio y al agotamiento físico que produce la actividad, Yolanda se encuentra solicitando un crédito para la compra de un molino eléctrico, olla, asador y un horno, con el fin de disminuir el cansancio y aumentar su capacidad de producción lo que conduce a un incremento en sus ingresos que se verá reflejado en el mejoramiento de la calidad de vida. Espera que su negocio le permita ahorrar para adecuar un local y no seguir laborando desde su vivienda.
texts.en: Yolanda is 64 years old and she is a very enterprising woman.  She has lived in Itagüí, Colombia for more than 30 years and makes and sells cornbread cakes.  This is her source of income.  She rises early every day and begins her task of making an average of 80 cakes a day, which she distributes in her neighborhood.  Because of the fatigue from the work, she is asking for a loan to buy an electric mill, pot, cooker, and oven so that she will not be so exhausted and can increase her production capability and quality life.  She hopes that her business will make it possible for her to save up to acquire a shop so that she will not need to continue to work from her home.

loans.use: to buy cooking equipment.

loans.name: Nino

texts.en:
Nino is 30 years old. She lives in Tsnori District with her 52-year-old mother and retired grandmother. Nino requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of the income for the family is the monthly pension of Nino’s grandmother. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Nino requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisions provision of business start-up and restart-up credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit, Nino will cover the costs of purchasing her stock of basic groceries. She owns a small commercial space where she will start a grocery store. As Nino doesn’t have to pay rent, the business will be more profitable and with the profit she plans to increase the turnover in her trade business gradually. Nino will work hard and she will be able to improve the living conditions for her family. With this loan, her family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market in the event they need them.

loans.use: To purchase her stock of basic groceries to open a grocery store

loans.name: Gocha

texts.en:
Gocha is 46 years old. He lives in the Gurjaani District with his retired parents. 

Gocha requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

His family owns a vineyard and a small agricultural plot of land. Gocha and his father harvest grapes to make wine, which they sell locally at the markets. They earn a small monthly income, which is the only source of income of the family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Gocha has requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products as they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.
